Comment: Triggered by the user pressing a button that says something like "Discuss the information with the app" while the user is looking at p1's data
Print: Which time period would you like to look at?
Ok, let's look at week 1 to week 8 then.

Comment: Case1: User selects any period across the first 8 weeks, where there has been a steady increase in temperature difference.
Print: We can see that the temperature difference between your healthy foot and your foot ulcer increased. This means it's likely that your foot ulcer has been getting worse. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if we can understand why your foot ulcer has been getting worse?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Let's look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you are at home, when you are at work and when you are out.
We can see that during this time period you often didn’t wear your boot while you were at home.

We can see that you take around {{p1u1stepsHome}} steps a week while you are at home. Because you weren't wearing your boot much at home, this means that you weren't wearing your boot for many of the steps you took.
In total you only wore your boot for {{p1u1stepsPercTotal}}% of the steps you took. It's likely that your foot ulcer has got worse because you haven't been wearing your boot as much as you should.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active. This means you need to wear it when you are at home as well as when you go out.
Thanks for talking with me. I hope this has been helpful. Bye!

Print: Why not?

In total you only wore your boot for {{p1u1stepsPercTotal}}% of the steps you took. It's likely that your foot ulcer has got worse because you haven't been wearing your boot as much as you should.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active. This means you need to wear it when you are at home as well as when you go out.

Comment: Case2: User selects any period across weeks 9 and 10, where there has been a modest decrease in temperature difference.
Print: Ok, let's look at week 9 to week 10 then.

We can see that the temperature difference between your healthy foot and your foot ulcer decreased a bit. This means it's likely that your foot ulcer has been getting better. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if we can understand why your foot ulcer has been getting better?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Let's look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you are at home, when you are at work and when you are out.

We can see that you always wear your boot while you were at work. We can also see that you were wearing your boot for quite a lot of the steps you took while you were at home. And you almost always wear your boot while you are out.
In total you were  wearing your boot for {{p1u2stepsPercTotal}}% of the steps you took. It's likely your ulcer has started to improve because you have been wearing your boot quite a lot of the time.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active.
Thanks for talking with me. I hope this has been helpful. Bye!

Comment: Case3: User selects any period across weeks 11 and 12, where there has been a sharp decrease in temperature difference.
Print: Ok, let's look at week 11 to week 12 then.

We can see that the temperature difference between your healthy foot and your foot ulcer decreased. This means it's likely that your foot ulcer has been getting better. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if we can understand why your foot ulcer has been getting better?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Let's look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you are at home, when you are at work and when you are out.

We can see that you always wore your boot while you were at work. We can also see that you were wearing your boot for most of the steps you took while you were at home. And you almost always wear your boot while you are out.
In total you were wearing your boot for {{p1u3stepsPercTotal}}% of the steps you took over this period. This is great!
You should keep wearing your boot! For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active.
Thanks for talking with me. I hope this has been helpful. Bye!

Comment: Case4: User selects any period that crosses the boundary of week 8 and 9, where the temperature difference switches from increasing to decreasing.
Print: Ok, let's look at week 7 to week 10 then.

We can see that in weeks 7 and 8, the temperature difference between your healthy foot and your foot ulcer increased. This means it's likely that your foot ulcer has been getting worse. But in weeks 9 and 10, the temperature difference between your healthy foot and your foot ulcer decreased. This means it's likely that your foot ulcer has been getting better. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if we can understand why your foot ulcer has been getting better?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Let's look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you are at home, when you are at work and when you are out.
We can see that up in weeks 7 and 8, you usually didn't wear your boot at home, even though you took around {{p1u4stepsHome}} steps a week at home.
In total you only wore your boot for {{p1u4stepsPercTotalA}}% of the steps you took. It's likely that your foot ulcer has got worse because you haven't been wearing your boot as much as you should.
There was a change at the end of week 8 and you started wearing your boot more often while you were at home.
In weeks 9 and 10, you wore your boot for {{p1u4stepsPercTotalB}}% of the steps you took.  It's likely that your foot ulcer started to improve because you started wearing your boot more.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active. This means you need to wear it when you are at home as well as when you go out.
Thanks for talking with me. I hope this has been helpful.

Comment: If No, then
Print: Ok, I’ll ask you again later. Bye!

Comment: If Because I’m busy, then
Print: Ok, you know where I am if you need me. Bye!

Comment: If Because I don’t need you to explain it to me, then

Comment: This dialogue assumes persona 1 at the end of week 12. Triggered by the researcher (to simulate the system being triggered by what it has seen in the data) the system will initiate the following dialogue.
Print: Hi, you are doing really well with your boot at the moment! Have a look at the information for the last two weeks (so for weeks 11 and 12).
This week you have worn your boot for {{p1s1stepsPercTotal}}% of all the steps you took!

CondJmp.msg: I think my boot has given me back ache. Is there anything I can do to make my back hurt less?
That's good, has my ulcer improved?

Comment: If I can’t talk now, then
Print: Ok, you know where I am if you need me. Bye!

Comment: If I’ve been making myself wear my boot but it’s been giving me really bad back ache, is there anything I can do to make my back hurt less?, then
Print: If you have another boot or shoe that’s a similar height to your boot then you could try wearing that on your healthy foot. This might reduce your back ache.
I’ve sent a message to your healthcare team to let them know that you might be suffering from back ache. They will be able to talk to you about different things you can try to make your pain better.

It’s really important that you keep wearing your boot. If you take a look at the temperature difference between your ulcer and your healthy foot then you can see that it's gone down by {{p1saTemp}} degrees over the past 2 weeks.
This is what we want to see, it suggests that your ulcer is improving. If you continue to wear your boot for most of your steps then we can expect your ulcer to keep getting better.
The foot clinic team will discuss your progress with you in more detail the next time you see them. You should keep wearing your boot, you are doing great!

Comment: If Great, has my ulcer improved?, then
Print: If you take a look at the temperature difference between your ulcer and your healthy foot then you can see that it's gone down by {{p1saTemp}} degrees over the past 2 weeks.
This is what we want to see, it suggests that your ulcer is improving. If you continue to wear your boot for most of your steps then we can expect your ulcer to keep getting better.
The foot clinic team will discuss your progress with you in more detail the next time you see them. You should keep wearing your boot, you are doing great! Bye!

Comment: This dialogue assumes persona 1 at the end of week 12. The researcher triggers the dialogue to simulate that, as per the patient's preferences, every Sunday at 6pm the system will initiate a dialogue with the patient to review their progress.
Print: Hi, how's your week been?

CondJmp.msg: I don't want to talk to you now

Comment: If I don't want to talk to you now, then
Print: Ok, you know where I am if you need me. Bye.

Comment: If Great|Ok, then
Print: Glad to hear that!

Comment: If Really awful, then
Print: I'm sorry to hear that, I hope next week is better for you.
How have you been getting on with wearing your boot this week (so week 12)?

CondJmp.msg: Good, I've barely taken it off
I don't think I've worn it as much as I should have done
